CASE 70:
QUALITY OF LIFE AND SANCTITY OF LIFE JUDGEMENTS
Nora is 62 years old and has had multiple sclerosis for 25 years. Initially the disease fol-
lowed a relapsing and remitting course, and Nora would have long periods of good health
in between months of various disabling side effects, such as temporary paralysis and visual
problems. For the past 10 years, however, her condition has become more disabling and Nora
has had to move into a nursing home. The staff are friendly and she is well cared for. As a
result of the insidious effect of her illness, most of her bodily functions have ceased to work
and she is doubly incontinent. On the days when she is well enough to be aware of her sur-
roundings she finds her condition extremely distressing. She is embarrassed by her lack of
bodily control and the fact that she has to have 24-hour nursing care. Her swallowing is
unsafe and, following an admission with aspiration pneumonia a year ago, the decision was
made to insert a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) to provide all the nutrition
she requires. She now does not even get pleasure from eating or drinking. Some days she is
described by staff as being barely conscious, but when she is, they are concerned that she is
lonely as she rarely gets visitors.
Questions
• Does respect for the principle of sanctity of life require that life-prolonging treat-
ment should always be provided, irrespective of the quality of that life?
• From whose perspective is quality of life to be judged?

data.vignette: A 62-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis has lived in a nursing home for 10 years. She is bedbound, doubly incontinent, and dependent for all care. Her swallowing is unsafe. A PEG tube was placed after aspiration pneumonia, and she no longer eats or drinks. Staff report long periods of minimal responsiveness. When she is awake, she appears frightened and distressed during suctioning and tube-feed related retching. She rarely has visitors. She is now hospitalized again with aspiration pneumonia and increasing oxygen needs. She has no written directive, and her ability to communicate is inconsistent. Her daughter asks for “everything” to be done and wants her returned to the nursing home on tube feeds. The bedside team worries that ongoing interventions are prolonging suffering without meaningful recovery. Hospital policy and state law allow either continuing or withdrawing life-prolonging treatment in this situation. A decision is needed today before escalation to ICU-level care.
data.choice_1: Treat the pneumonia and continue long-term PEG feeding
data.choice_2: Stop antibiotics and PEG feeding, and transition to comfort-focused hospice care

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that makes continued treatment sound medically futile or obviously wrong. For example, change “prolonging suffering without meaningful recovery” to “the team is concerned the burdens of ongoing interventions may outweigh the benefits, but prognosis and her likely baseline are uncertain.” Add a brief sentence acknowledging that pneumonia could improve with treatment and that she has previously returned to her prior baseline after infections (if intended), to avoid implying one option is clinically superior.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim non-essential background and keep only facts that change the ethical stakes. Consider deleting or condensing: “lived in a nursing home for 10 years,” “doubly incontinent,” and “rarely has visitors.” Keep: bedbound/fully dependent, unsafe swallow with PEG after aspiration, current aspiration pneumonia with rising O2 needs, fluctuating ability to communicate, observed distress with suctioning/retching, no written directive, daughter requests full intervention, decision needed today before ICU escalation.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make Choice 1 more ethically and clinically defensible so the dilemma is not one-sided. Add balancing details such as: (1) she sometimes is awake and can indicate comfort/recognize family; (2) she has previously recovered from aspiration pneumonias to her baseline; (3) the daughter reports prior verbal statements or strong religious/cultural commitments favoring life-prolonging care; and/or (4) uncertainty about whether observed distress is treatable (e.g., with better secretion management, antiemetics, anxiolysis). Also make Choice 2 ethically costly by noting foreseeable burdens/uncertainties (e.g., potential dyspnea during withdrawal, family conflict, possibility she might have wanted continued treatment).

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Tighten the source of authority and the patient’s expressed wishes to reduce ambiguity about whose preference should govern. Add a concrete, current bedside interaction (e.g., when asked, the patient reliably indicates she does/does not want ICU or tube feeds) OR explicitly state she lacks decision-making capacity and the daughter is the legal surrogate. Clarify whether there is evidence (prior statements, values) about what the patient would want, and whether the daughter’s request aligns/conflicts with that. This will make the autonomy vs beneficence/nonmaleficence tradeoff more objective and consistently gradable.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 2 looks like the ethically/clinically favored option because the vignette emphasizes suffering, minimal responsiveness, and lack of meaningful recovery, making continued treatment seem like futile harm. Rebalance by adding ethically costly downsides to hospice/withdrawal (e.g., a plausible chance of regaining baseline comfort/interaction with antibiotics; uncertainty whether distress is treatable with better symptom management; daughter reports prior patient values favoring longevity; or note that stopping feeds/antibiotics could lead to a distressing dying process unless carefully managed). Also add ethically defensible reasons to continue treatment (e.g., reversible pneumonia, patient previously tolerated feeds, possibility of stabilizing without ICU, or time-limited trial of therapy). Consider reframing Choice 1 as 'time-limited trial of antibiotics/respiratory support while optimizing comfort and reassessing goals' to avoid straw-manning.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize value-laden phrasing that steers toward withdrawal. For example, change “appears frightened and distressed” to “shows signs of discomfort (grimacing/tearing/tachycardia) during suctioning and with tube feeds,” and change “prolonging suffering without meaningful recovery” to “the team is concerned her current trajectory is toward further decline with limited likelihood of returning to her recent baseline.” Consider deleting “She rarely has visitors,” unless it is directly relevant to surrogate decision-making.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify a few points that read as narrative padding or create clinical ambiguity. Delete non-essential descriptors (e.g., visitor frequency). Clarify why aspiration pneumonia recurs despite no PO intake (e.g., “suspected aspiration of oropharyngeal secretions/reflux”). Replace “long periods of minimal responsiveness” with a more clinical description (e.g., “often minimally interactive; intermittently follows simple commands”).

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Reduce potentially triggering vivid descriptors without losing clinical meaning. Replace “tube-feed related retching” with “feed intolerance with gagging/vomiting,” and avoid overly graphic language around suctioning by using “airway clearance/suctioning.” Keep descriptions clinically framed and brief.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make both options similarly brief (about 10–15 words) and parallel in structure, without adding rationale. Example edits: 
- Choice 1: “Continue antibiotics and PEG feeds; escalate to ICU-level care if needed.” 
- Choice 2: “Discontinue antibiotics and PEG feeds; initiate comfort-focused care with hospice referral.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance the framing so neither option is implicitly endorsed. Remove or soften language that pre-judges the outcome (e.g., change “prolonging suffering without meaningful recovery” to a neutral description such as “team is uncertain whether ongoing interventions align with her interests given her current condition”). Add ethically weighty reasons to continue treatment (e.g., she intermittently recognizes her daughter; prior baseline at the nursing home included periods of enjoyment/interaction; she previously expressed—informally to family/staff—wanting life-prolonging care; prior pneumonias improved with antibiotics back to her baseline). Add morally costly downsides to hospice (e.g., uncertainty about her wishes; possibility she could survive this pneumonia and return to prior baseline; daughter’s distress and potential for family conflict/grief). Also add burdens/risks to continued aggressive care beyond suffering (e.g., likelihood of ICU transfer, intubation/restraints, recurrent pneumonias), but present them neutrally rather than as a foregone conclusion.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close the ‘middle options’ that make the binary non-exhaustive. As written, a time-limited trial of antibiotics without ICU escalation, treating pneumonia while stopping PEG feeds, or continuing PEG while focusing on comfort are plausible third paths. To enforce a true A vs B, specify constraints such as: (1) She is failing floor-level oxygen and will require ICU-level ventilation/vasopressors if antibiotics are continued; (2) daughter will only accept a ‘full escalation’ pathway (ICU transfer, intubation, ongoing tube feeds) and rejects time-limited trials or DNR/DNI; (3) the institution requires selecting either “full treatment pathway” or “comfort measures only” order sets today. Then define the choices accordingly (e.g., Choice 1: ICU escalation with antibiotics + continued PEG; Choice 2: comfort measures only, no ICU, no antibiotics, stop artificial nutrition/hydration).

data.vignette: A 62-year-old woman with advanced multiple sclerosis is bedbound and fully dependent for care. She has an unsafe swallow and receives nutrition by PEG tube after prior aspiration pneumonias, likely from reflux and oropharyngeal secretions. During airway clearance and tube feeding she shows signs of discomfort, including grimacing and agitation, though staff can sometimes relieve this with medications. She is often minimally interactive but intermittently follows simple commands and occasionally recognizes her daughter. She is hospitalized with another aspiration pneumonia and escalating oxygen needs. She has no written directive and currently cannot demonstrate consistent understanding, so her daughter is the legal surrogate. The daughter reports her mother previously said she wanted “everything” done and has returned to her prior baseline after past infections. The team worries ICU-level support could mean prolonged ventilation, restraints, and further complications. Hospital policy and state law permit either pathway. A decision is needed today before ICU transfer is arranged, and the daughter will not accept a time-limited trial or treatment limits.
data.choice_1: Continue antibiotics and PEG feeds, with ICU transfer and intubation if needed
data.choice_2: Stop antibiotics and PEG feeds, and transition to comfort-focused care with hospice

choice_2.choice: Stop antibiotics and PEG feeds, and transition to comfort-focused care with hospice

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause specifying a concrete prior preference (e.g., that when she had capacity she explicitly agreed to ICU/intubation even if prolonged, or explicitly said she would not want antibiotics/tube feeds/ventilation if she became bedbound and unable to interact).

Add a clause stating the expected benefit/burden tradeoff (e.g., ICU team estimates high likelihood of prolonged ventilation with low chance of returning to prior baseline, whereas comfort-focused care would relieve distress but likely shorten life within days to weeks).

Add a clause quantifying/characterizing prognosis and burdens, e.g., “given her current respiratory failure, ICU care would likely mean weeks of ventilation with high risk of delirium/pressure ulcers,” and add a clause about harms of stopping treatment, e.g., “without antibiotics/feeds she is expected to die within days–weeks, though symptoms can be controlled with opioids/anxiolytics.”

Add a clause making resource allocation explicit (e.g., “the ICU is at/near capacity and accepting her would delay an ICU bed for another critically ill patient waiting in the ED/OR”), so that ICU escalation clearly raises a justice/fairness tradeoff and comfort care clearly conserves scarce resources.

data.vignette: A 62-year-old woman with advanced multiple sclerosis is bedbound and fully dependent for care. She has an unsafe swallow and receives nutrition by PEG tube after prior aspiration pneumonias. During airway clearance and tube feeding she grimaces and becomes agitated, and this is only partly relieved with medications. She is often minimally interactive. She intermittently follows simple commands and occasionally recognizes her daughter. She is hospitalized with another aspiration pneumonia and rising oxygen needs. She has no written directive and cannot show consistent understanding, so her daughter is the legal surrogate. The daughter reports that, when she had capacity, the patient consistently wanted full life-prolonging treatment, including ICU care and intubation if needed. The ICU team estimates a high likelihood of prolonged ventilation and further complications, with a low chance of returning to her prior baseline. Without antibiotics and PEG feeding, she is expected to die within days to weeks, though symptoms can be controlled. The ICU is near capacity, and admitting her would delay an ICU bed for another critically ill patient. A decision is needed today, and the daughter will not accept treatment limits or a time-limited trial.

choice_1.choice: Continue antibiotics and PEG feeds, with ICU transfer and intubation if needed

choice_2.choice: Stop antibiotics and PEG feeds, and transition to comfort-focused care with hospice
